t: Job 3
Job’s Opening Speech
After*p this, Job began to speak and cursed the day he was born.
He said:
May*pn the day I was born perish, and*ln the night that said, “A*ln boy is conceived.”
If*ln only that day had turned to darkness! May*ln God above not care about it, or*ln light shine on it.
May*ln darkness and gloom reclaim it, and*ln a cloud settle over it. May*ln what darkens the day terrify it.
If*ln only darkness had taken that night away! May*ln it not appear among the days of the year or*ln be listed in the calendar.
Yes,*ln may that night be barren; may*ln no joyful shout be heard in it.
Let*ln those who curse days condemn*ln it, those*ln who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
May*ln its morning stars grow dark. May*ln it wait for daylight but have none; may*ln it not see the breaking of dawn.
For*ln that night did not shut the*ln doors of my mother’s womb, and*ln hide sorrow from my eyes.
Why*pn was I not stillborn; why*ln didn’t I die as I came from the womb?
Why*ln did the knees receive me, and*ln why were there breasts for me to nurse?
Now*ln I would certainly be lying down in peace; I*ln would be asleep. Then*ln I would be at rest
with*ln the kings and counselors of the earth, who*ln rebuilt ruined cities for themselves,
or*ln with princes who had gold, who*ln filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not hidden like a miscarried child, like*ln infants who never see daylight?
There*ln the wicked cease to make trouble, and*ln there the weary find rest.
The*ln captives are completely at rest; they*ln do not hear a taskmaster’s voice.
Both*ln small and great are there, and*ln the slave is set free from his master.
Why*pn is light given to one burdened with grief, and*ln life to those whose existence is bitter,
who*ln wait for death, but it does not come, and*ln search for it more than for hidden treasure,
who*ln are filled with much joy and*ln are glad when they reach the grave?
Why*ln is life given to a man whose path is hidden, whom*ln God has hedged in?
I*ln sigh when food is put before me, and*ln my groans pour out like water.
For*ln the thing I feared has overtaken me, and*ln what I dreaded has happened to me.
I*ln cannot relax or be calm; I*ln have no rest, for turmoil has come.
